TopicTitle: This may seem like an odd question..

Articles.Content:
Where do Kerbals 'go' when they enter a pod?

I remember the first time I used 'no clip' in Half life 2 I found a little box hidden in a corner of the game world. Inside was Dr Breen! It was the model that is projected onto the big holo screens as you enter the train station. You can have a lot of fun with that!

Anyway, so I know the kerbals are not rendered 'inside' the pod so 'where' are they?

MJ

They are parts when on EVA. When entering the vessel, the part despawns and the "soul" of the Kerbal is put into the pod's internal info. Then a Kerbal IVA model is spawned into the Command Pod.

When they are in IVA mode, they are inside a special IVA space that is hidden from the main scene but actually exists where the command pods are. The IVA cameras (and kerbal's eye view) look into the internal space and the external space and scaled space. External space only shows External and Scaled spaces, and hides the Internal space.

I think it is if the game seriously bugs out. A few mods implement pods that have visible IVA spaces. Problem is of course that the lighting is somehow offset 90 degrees from where it should be, so thun sun lights the wrong side of objects.

In games such as Half-Life and Portal, it appears to be the case that levels all exist in the same space. Thus to have something like a mini-map, an IVA view, etc., you have to stick them way off to the side, underground, etc.

In Unity, a single scene can have multiple "layers", such that multiple sets of objects can occupy the same place in the scene but only be visible to certain cameras and thus only render where the developers want them to. Thus, in order to reveal the IVA view in the main view, one would have to change the layers visible to that camera to include those meant only for the IVA cameras. No amount of no-clipping or flying around will make them appear.
